bubble_tea.serving_description: 700 ml cup with pearls at full sugar level
bubble_tea.notes: Large bubble tea with toppings is very high in sugar and calories while providing little protein or fibre. Taken frequently it can easily exceed daily sugar recommendations and contribute to weight gain and dental issues.
common_myths: Bubble tea is healthy because it has milk and tea
The pearls are good fiber
healthier_swaps: Choose 0–25% sugar instead of full sweetness
Skip pearls or heavy toppings, or share a cup with a friend
Pick the smallest serving size instead of upsizing
Limit bubble tea to an occasional treat rather than a daily habit

evidence.statistic: A 700 ml bubble tea with toppings can contain around 469 kcal and roughly 11 teaspoons of sugar.
evidence.source_name: Mount Alvernia Hospital & Singapore Health Promotion Board resources

nasi_lemak.serving_description: 1 plate with coconut rice, fried chicken or fish, egg, sambal and peanuts
nasi_lemak.notes: Because of coconut milk rice, fried items and sambal, nasi lemak is energy-dense and high in saturated fat and sodium. Eating it often without adjustments can make a calorie deficit hard to maintain.
common_myths: Nasi lemak is a balanced meal because it has all food groups
Eating it for breakfast is healthier than other times
healthier_swaps: Ask for less rice and more cucumber or vegetables
Choose grilled or non-fried protein where available
Go easy on sambal and gravy
Balance the rest of the day with lighter meals

evidence.statistic: Calorie charts place one plate of nasi lemak roughly between 494 and 600 kcal depending on ingredients.
evidence.source_name: Local calorie charts and nutrition databases

chicken_rice.serving_description: 1 plate Hainanese chicken rice with skin, fragrant rice and sauces
chicken_rice.notes: Chicken rice provides protein but is also high in calories and sodium due to the fragrant rice cooked with fat and the sauces. Regular large portions can slow weight-loss progress.
common_myths: Chicken rice is healthy because it's steamed chicken
The rice is plain and low in calories
healthier_swaps: Ask for more chicken and less rice
Remove the skin to reduce saturated fat
Use less soy sauce and dark sauce
Add a side of vegetables or soup

evidence.statistic: One serving of chicken rice is commonly estimated at 600–670 kcal with high sodium content.
evidence.source_name: HealthHub Singapore and local nutrition charts

fried_chicken.serving_description: 1 medium piece of deep-fried chicken with skin
fried_chicken.notes: Fried chicken offers protein but also a lot of added fat and sodium from the batter and deep-frying. Frequent intake can raise cardiovascular risk and make a calorie deficit harder.
common_myths: It's fine as long as I remove the skin
Fried chicken is just protein so it's healthy
healthier_swaps: Choose grilled or roasted chicken more often
Remove skin and visible batter where possible
Avoid pairing with sugary drinks and large fries

evidence.statistic: Fast-food style fried chicken portions typically provide 250–350 kcal per piece with high fat and sodium.

soft_drink_can.serving_description: 1 can of regular sugar-sweetened soft drink
soft_drink_can.notes: Soft drinks provide a lot of sugar and calories in liquid form without fibre or nutrients, making it very easy to overconsume them without feeling full.
common_myths: Diet soda is completely safe to drink unlimited amounts
One can a day won't hurt
healthier_swaps: Switch to water, sparkling water or unsweetened tea most of the time
If you drink soft drinks, keep them as an occasional treat and choose smaller cans
Try flavoured water or zero-sugar drinks if appropriate for your health

evidence.statistic: In Singapore, more than half of daily sugar intake comes from beverages, and average sugar intake is about 58 g per day.
evidence.source_name: Singapore Health Promotion Board – Nutri-Grade information

greek_yogurt_plain_low_fat.serving_description: 170 g tub of plain low-fat Greek yogurt
greek_yogurt_plain_low_fat.notes: Plain Greek yogurt is high in protein and relatively low in calories, making it a good base for snacks and breakfasts when combined with fruit, nuts or oats.
common_myths: All yogurt is the same
Flavored yogurt is just as healthy as plain
healthier_swaps: Choose plain versions and add your own fruit instead of pre-sweetened flavours
Use yogurt instead of cream in some recipes
Pair with berries and a small handful of nuts for a balanced snack

evidence.statistic: Typical plain Greek yogurt tubs provide around 15–20 g protein per 100–120 kcal serving.

oatmeal_with_milk.serving_description: 1 bowl of rolled oats cooked with low-fat milk (about 40 g dry oats)
oatmeal_with_milk.notes: Oats provide fibre and slow-release carbohydrates that help with fullness and stable energy. Without too much added sugar, they support both weight control and training.
common_myths: Oats are boring and tasteless
Instant oats are just as healthy as regular oats
healthier_swaps: Sweeten lightly with fruit instead of large amounts of sugar or syrup
Add protein powder, yogurt or nuts if you need more protein and staying power
Avoid instant flavoured sachets that are high in added sugar

evidence.statistic: Randomised trials link higher whole-grain and oat intake with better cholesterol and satiety.
evidence.source_name: Systematic reviews of whole grains and metabolic health

char_kway_teow.serving_description: 1 plate of fried flat rice noodles with egg, cockles, Chinese sausage and bean sprouts
char_kway_teow.notes: Char kway teow is stir-fried with a lot of oil and dark soy sauce, making it very high in fat and sodium. One plate can contain most of your daily sodium limit.
common_myths: It's healthy because it has vegetables
The noodles are the unhealthy part, not the oil
healthier_swaps: Ask for less oil when ordering
Share a plate with a friend and add a side of vegetables
Skip the Chinese sausage to reduce saturated fat
Balance with lighter meals for the rest of the day

evidence.statistic: A typical plate of char kway teow contains 700-800 kcal and can exceed 1400 mg sodium.
evidence.source_name: Health Promotion Board Singapore nutrition database

laksa.serving_description: 1 bowl of curry laksa with noodles, tofu puffs, prawns and cockles
laksa.notes: Laksa's rich coconut curry base makes it high in saturated fat and sodium. The gravy alone can account for much of the calories.
common_myths: Laksa is light because it's a soup
The spices make it burn fat
healthier_swaps: Ask for less gravy or don't finish all the soup
Choose more seafood and vegetables, less tofu puffs
Pair with plain water instead of sugary drinks
Keep it as an occasional meal, not weekly

evidence.statistic: A bowl of laksa typically provides 500-650 kcal with high saturated fat from coconut milk.
evidence.source_name: Singapore nutrition charts and HPB resources

roti_prata_plain.serving_description: 2 pieces of plain roti prata with curry
roti_prata_plain.notes: Roti prata is made with ghee or oil, making it calorie-dense. Two pieces can be a significant portion of daily calories, especially when eaten with sugar or sweet fillings.
common_myths: Plain prata is low-calorie because it's just bread
Eating prata with curry makes it healthier
healthier_swaps: Limit to 1 piece instead of 2 or 3
Pair with curry for dipping instead of drizzling sugar
Add a side of vegetables or egg for protein
Choose thosai as a lighter alternative when available

evidence.statistic: Two pieces of plain prata provide approximately 300-400 kcal depending on size and oil used.

instant_noodles.serving_description: 1 packet of instant noodles with full seasoning
instant_noodles.notes: Instant noodles are extremely high in sodium, with one packet often exceeding 80% of the daily recommended limit. They're also low in protein, fibre and micronutrients.
common_myths: Instant noodles are cheap and harmless
The soup is the healthy part
It's fine to eat daily as long as you add vegetables
healthier_swaps: Use only half the seasoning packet
Add an egg, tofu or lean meat for protein
Load up with vegetables like bok choy, mushrooms and carrots
Choose lower-sodium brands or fresh noodles when possible

evidence.statistic: Regular instant noodle consumption has been linked with increased metabolic syndrome risk in some studies.
evidence.source_name: Journal of Nutrition research on instant noodle consumption patterns

kaya_toast_set.serving_description: 2 slices kaya toast with butter, 2 soft-boiled eggs and coffee with condensed milk
kaya_toast_set.notes: A traditional kaya toast set contains significant sugar from kaya spread and condensed milk in the coffee. The eggs provide protein, but overall it's a high-calorie, high-sugar breakfast.
common_myths: Eggs make this a healthy breakfast
Kaya is healthier than jam because it's made from coconut
healthier_swaps: Ask for less butter or skip it entirely
Request kopi-c (coffee with evaporated milk) instead of kopi (condensed milk)
Spread kaya thinly or choose 1 slice instead of 2
Add a side of fruit for more nutrients

evidence.statistic: A typical kaya toast breakfast set provides 400-500 kcal with 15-20g sugar.

potato_chips.serving_description: 1 small packet (28g) of regular potato chips
potato_chips.notes: Potato chips are energy-dense and easy to overconsume. One small packet has limited nutrients and can lead to eating multiple servings without feeling satisfied.
common_myths: Baked chips are much healthier than fried
It's just potatoes so it can't be that bad
healthier_swaps: Portion out a small amount instead of eating from the bag
Choose air-popped popcorn or roasted chickpeas
Pair with protein like cheese or nuts to increase satiety
Save chips for occasional treats, not daily snacks

evidence.statistic: Ultra-processed snack foods are associated with higher calorie intake and weight gain in observational studies.
evidence.source_name: Research on ultra-processed foods and health outcomes

mixed_vegetable_salad.serving_description: 1 large bowl of mixed greens, tomatoes, cucumbers, carrots with light vinaigrette
mixed_vegetable_salad.notes: Vegetable salads are low in calories and high in fibre, vitamins and minerals. They help with fullness and provide important nutrients for overall health.
common_myths: Salads don't fill you up
All salads are healthy even with lots of dressing
healthier_swaps: Add grilled chicken, tofu, or beans for protein
Use dressing on the side and dip your fork
Include a variety of colorful vegetables for different nutrients
Top with seeds or nuts for healthy fats and crunch

evidence.statistic: Higher vegetable intake is consistently associated with lower risk of chronic diseases and better weight management.
evidence.source_name: WHO and national dietary guidelines on vegetables

grilled_chicken_breast.notes: Grilled chicken breast is one of the best lean protein sources. It's high in protein, low in fat, and versatile for many meals.
common_myths: You need to eat chicken breast every day to build muscle
Chicken breast is boring and tasteless
healthier_swaps: Season with herbs and spices instead of heavy sauces
Marinate to keep it moist and flavorful
Pair with whole grains and vegetables for a balanced meal
Rotate with fish, tofu or legumes for variety

evidence.statistic: Lean poultry is recommended as a primary protein source in most healthy eating patterns worldwide.
evidence.source_name: Dietary Guidelines for Americans and similar international guidelines

salmon_grilled.notes: Salmon is rich in omega-3 fatty acids, which support heart and brain health. It's an excellent protein source despite being higher in calories than white fish.
common_myths: Salmon is too fatty and will make you gain weight
All fish are the same nutritionally
healthier_swaps: Choose wild-caught when available and affordable
Grill, bake or steam instead of frying
Pair with vegetables and brown rice for a complete meal
Aim for 2-3 servings of fatty fish per week

evidence.statistic: Regular consumption of omega-3 rich fish is associated with reduced cardiovascular disease risk.
evidence.source_name: American Heart Association fish consumption recommendations

brown_rice_cooked.notes: Brown rice is a whole grain that provides more fibre, vitamins and minerals than white rice. It helps with sustained energy and digestive health.
common_myths: Brown rice is always better than white rice for everyone
You must completely replace white rice with brown rice
healthier_swaps: Mix brown and white rice if you prefer the taste
Control portions to 1/2 to 1 cup per meal
Pair with plenty of protein and vegetables
Try other whole grains like quinoa or barley for variety

evidence.statistic: Whole grain consumption is associated with lower risk of type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease.
evidence.source_name: Meta-analyses of whole grain intake and health outcomes
